newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan begins Afghan mediation mission.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan begins Afghan mediation mission.

text.p: Pakistan sent a senior diplomat to northern Afghanistan on Tuesday on a mission to persuade warring factions to hold peace talks which Islamabad plans to host, government officials said.

The officials, quoted by the state media, said Iftikhar Murshed, a senior official in the foreign ministry, would meet northern opposition leader General Abdul Malik and his allies in an alliance fighting the dominant Taleban Islamic movement.
Murshed left for the opposition-held northern Afghan town of Mazar-i-Sharif after holding talks with Taleban officials in the southern town of Kandahar on Friday.
"The Pakistani diplomat is believed to be taking a set of peace proposals from the Taleban leadership to the opposition alliance," the official APP news agency said.
It quoted Pakistani officials as saying Islamabad was not proposing any agreement of its own but was just to make the warring sides agree on a minimum agenda to initiate a dialogue.

Last month, Islamabad proposed hosting a conference of Afghanistan's five immediate neighbours -- Iran, Pakistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan -- and the United States and Russia under U.N. auspices to find ways for peace in the war-shattered country.

Pakistan recognised the Taleban government in late May after the purist Islamic militia briefly captured Mazar-i-Sharif with Malik's help and was followed by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
Islamabad is accused by ethnic Uzbek and Tajik opposition factions of helping the mainly ethnic Pashtun Taleban, which controls more than two-thirds of Afghanistan, including the capital Kabul.
Murshed's trip to the north comes a day after a former Afghan president, Sibghatullah Mojadidi, left Pakistan for his own peace mission to north Afghanistan via Tehran.
Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati held talks with Mojadidi on Tuesday, Iran's official IRNA news agency said.

Mojadidi launched his mission, aimed at securing a ceasefire and an exchange of prisoners, after consulting the Taleban and Malik, who controls the ethnic Uzbek forces in the north, according to a spokesman for the former president.
The Taleban want Malik to free hundreds of Taleban fighters captured in Mazar-i-Sharif last month.

The Taleban captives include some key leaders who had gone to Mazar-i-Sharif for talks with Malik, who had made a short-lived alliance with the Taleban against former opposition warlord General Abdul Rashid Dostum.
Malik turned on the Taleban at the end of May, linking up with a Shi'ite Moslem Hezb-i-Wahdat faction to drive them from Mazar-i-Sharif after 15 hours of street fighting.
